title: copingmethods
copingmethods
text: copingmethods package includes two datasets: depression_age: dataset provides annual data depression rates different age groups across countries, 1990 2019. allows analysis trends age-specific depression rates time. percent_copingmethods: dataset contains information percentage usage various coping methods reported individuals across countries, specifically year 2020. data useful comparing different countries approach mental health management. Example: Loading Exploring Datasets can preview structure datasets follows:

what: View the first few rows of the depression_age dataset
title: copingmethods

what: View the first few rows of the percent_copingmethods dataset
title: copingmethods

title: copingmethods
text: depression_age dataset includes following columns: Entity: country region data collected. Code: Country Code. Year: year data collected. Age Groups (e.g., Age_5_14, Age_15_19, etc.): percentage people age group reported experiencing depression. row represents depression percentages various age groups given country year.

title: copingmethods
text: see depression rates specific country year:

title: copingmethods
text: percent_copingmethods dataset contains following columns: Entity: country region data collected. Code: Country code. Year: year data collection (2020). Coping Method Columns (e.g., Religious spiritual activities, Improved healthy lifestyle behaviors, etc.): percentage respondents reported using coping method. row represents percentage usage different coping methods given country.

title: copingmethods
text: see top coping methods used specific country, Brazil:
code: # Filter for Brazil in 2020 brazil_coping <- percent_copingmethods |>   filter(Entity == "Brazil")  print(brazil_coping) #>   Entity Code Year Religious spiritual activities #> 1 Brazil  BRA 2020                       53.72946 #>   Improved healthy lifestyle behaviors Made a change to work situation #> 1                             72.57038                        51.04526 #>   Made a change to personal relationships Talked to friends or family #> 1                                74.34573                    71.42405 #>   Took prescribed medication Spent time in nature #> 1                   44.71939              64.1756 #>   Talked to mental health professional #> 1                             46.25562

what: Visualizing Top Coping Methods Using ggplot2
title: copingmethods
text: example, let’s create plot shows top five entities based use “Religious spiritual activities” coping method.  plot shows top five entities reported highest percentages “Religious spiritual activities” coping mechanism. bar represents entity, gradient color indicating level usage.
code: library(ggplot2)  # `topfive`  topfive <- percent_copingmethods |>       arrange(desc(`Religious spiritual activities`)) |>       head()  # Create the plot ggplot(topfive, aes(x = reorder(Entity, `Religious spiritual activities`),                      y  = `Religious spiritual activities`,                      color = `Religious spiritual activities`)) +   geom_segment(aes(y = 0,                     yend = `Religious spiritual activities`,                    x = Entity,                     yend = Entity),                 linewidth = 3) +          # Line from y-axis to point   geom_point(size = 6) +                # Point at the end of each line   geom_text(aes(label = paste0(round(`Religious spiritual activities`, 2), "%")),              hjust = -0.3, size = 4.8) +                      scale_color_gradient(low = "lightblue", high = "darkblue") +  # Gradient from light to dark blue   labs(y = "Religious Spiritual Activities (%)",         x = "Entity",         title = "Top 5 Entities by Religious/Spiritual Activities") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(     plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 24 ),     # Center and resize title     axis.title.y = element_text(size = 22),                # Adjust x-axis label size     axis.title.x = element_text(size = 22),                # Adjust y-axis label size     axis.text.y = element_text(size = 20),                  # Adjust x-axis text size     axis.text.x = element_text(size = 20)                   # Adjust y-axis text size   ) #> Warning: Duplicated aesthetics after name standardisation: yend #> Duplicated aesthetics after name standardisation: yend

what: Launching the Interactive Shiny App with launch_copingmethods()
title: copingmethods
text: copingmethods package provides interactive Shiny application help users explore mental health trends. app can launched using launch_copingmethods() function, opens user-friendly interface visualize compare data. Function Description: launch_copingmethods() launch_copingmethods() function starts Shiny app included package. app provides interactive visualizations mental health trends, allowing users analyze depression rates across age groups compare coping methods used different countries. Arguments: function takes arguments. Return Value: function return value instead launches Shiny app default web browser. Example Usage:
code: # Launch the Shiny app to explore the datasets interactively launch_copingmethods()

title: copingmethods
text: app two main sections analyzing data: 1. Depression Age Analysis section, can view depression rates across different age groups selected country compare rates two years. Steps Use Depression Age Analysis: Select “Depression Age” option “Select Analysis Type”. Choose Country/Entity dropdown list. (Optional) Check “Show Average Entities” display dashed line representing average depression rate across countries selected year. Use Year slider select two years comparison. Outputs: Bar Chart: bar chart displays depression percentages age group selected country year. “Show Average” selected, dashed line shows average rate. Difference Table: table shows change depression percentage age group start year selected year. 2. Coping Methods Comparison section allows compare top coping methods two countries. Steps Use Coping Methods Comparison: Select “Coping Methods Comparison” option “Select Analysis Type”. Choose two Countries compare (choose “None” one view data one country). Adjust Number Top Coping Methods display 1 8. Outputs: Bar Chart: bar chart showing top coping methods selected countries, allowing visual comparison.

title: copingmethods
text: encounter issues using copingmethods package launching Shiny app, following tips may help resolve common problems. 1. Shiny App Launch launch_copingmethods() Problem: running launch_copingmethods(), app open, may see error message like: “find Shiny app directory. Try re-installing copingmethods.” Solution: Ensure copingmethods package correctly installed. Try reinstalling package necessary: Reinstall copingmethods package Verify copingmethods package installation includes Shiny app files. problem persists, consider re-installing package check installation errors. 2. Error: “object found” depression_age percent_copingmethods Problem: may encounter errors related depression_age percent_copingmethods found running examples visualizations. Solution: Ensure datasets loaded correctly package. datasets accessed directly copingmethods package namespace: resolve issue, re-install package, data files might missing corrupted. 3. Warning: “value argument names<-() must length x” Problem: warning might appear manipulating datasets names() function dplyr tidyverse. Solution: warning indicates mismatch length names assigned data frame vector. Check code assignments names() column renaming performed, ensuring number names matches columns values. 4. Shiny App Display Issues Layout Problems Problem: app layout may look misaligned, components may render correctly, especially see warnings bs_theme layout settings. Solution: Try clearing browser cache opening app different browser. Occasionally, old cached styles can interfere display updated content. layout issues persist, try running runApp() RStudio clean session: 5. Error Messages ggplot2 plotly Visualizations Problem: Errors related visualizations, “object found” unexpected behaviors plot. Solution: Double-check necessary libraries (ggplot2, plotly, etc.) loaded. problem specific Shiny app, ensure latest versions libraries installed. Inspect filter() pivot_longer() steps code ensure correct variable names data structures used. Errors often occur columns referenced code don’t match dataset. 6. Issues bslib bs_theme Settings Problem: Theme issues, font displaying color themes applying correctly, can arise bslib. Solution: Make sure bslib installed updated. can install update using: theme still apply correctly, try adjusting theme settings code ensuring required fonts available. fonts may require active internet connection load correctly. continue experience issues trying solutions, consult documentation shiny, ggplot2, relevant packages, seek help R community forums like Stack Overflow RStudio Community.
code: # Reinstall copingmethods package remotes::install_github("ETC5523-2024/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-praj0022") library(copingmethods) data("depression_age", package = "copingmethods") data("percent_copingmethods", package = "copingmethods") library(copingmethods) launch_copingmethods() install.packages("ggplot2") install.packages("plotly") install.packages("bslib")

title: copingmethods
text: guide provides overview functionalities copingmethods package, including dataset exploration, plotting examples, interactive Shiny app comprehensive mental health data analysis. Users can visualize compare coping methods depression trends across various age groups countries, making valuable tool exploring global mental health trends. Additionally, troubleshooting section included address common installation, loading, visualization issues, ensuring smooth experience using package.

Policy-makers interested understanding global trends mental health. Educators students want learn mental health trends interactive data exploration.

title: Tools to Explore Global Mental Health Trends in Depression and Coping Mechanisms
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(copingmethods) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(tidyr)   long_data <- percent_copingmethods |>   pivot_longer(     cols = -c(Entity, Code, Year),        # Pivot all columns except 'Entity', 'Code' and 'Year'     names_to = "Coping_Method",           # New column for coping method names     values_to = "Value"                   # New column for the values of coping methods   )   # Filter the data to only include rows where Entity is "Australia" filtered_data <- long_data %>%   filter(Entity == "Australia")  # Plot using the filtered data with a border around the bars and softer colors ggplot(filtered_data, aes(x = Entity, y = Value, fill = Coping_Method)) +   geom_col(position = "dodge", color = "black") +          # Add black border around bars   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Pastel1") +                 # Use a soft color palette   labs(x = "Entity", y = "Coping Method Value", title = "Coping Methods for Australia") +   theme_minimal()

what: copingmethods: Tools to Explore Global Mental Health Trends in Depression and Coping Mechanisms — copingmethods-package
title: copingmethods: Tools to Explore Global Mental Health Trends in Depression and Coping Mechanisms — copingmethods-package
text: `copingmethods` package offers tools explore mental health data, focusing depression rates across age groups coping mechanisms used different countries. package includes two datasets, `depression_age` (depression rates 1990 2019 age group) `percent_copingmethods` (coping methods data 2020). interactive Shiny app allows users analyze trends interactively.
